title: Uncle Tom's Cabin
subtitle: The Power of Literature (1852)

sections.title: A Book That Changed America
sections.summary: I'm Rebecca, fourteen years old, living in Boston. Everyone in my family is reading Uncle Tom's Cabin by Harriet Beecher Stowe. The novel was published this year, 1852, and it's become the most talked-about book in America.

sections.title: The Characters Come Alive
sections.summary: The characters in Uncle Tom's Cabin feel real to me. Uncle Tom isn't just a name in a newspaper story about slavery—he's a person I know through Mrs. Stowe's words.

sections.title: Reaction in the North
sections.summary: Uncle Tom's Cabin is everywhere in the North. It's selling faster than any book in American history—300,000 copies in the first year. Only the Bible sells more copies.

vocabulary.definition: 1852 anti-slavery novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe that influenced Northern opinion.
Author whose novel Uncle Tom's Cabin galvanized Northern opposition to slavery.
Main character in Stowe's novel—faithful slave sold away from family.
Cruel slave owner in novel who became symbol of slavery's brutality.
Character who fled slavery by crossing icy Ohio River with her baby.
Books and publications advocating end of slavery.
